William Morris once said,
"Have nothing in your house

13.text:
that you do not know to be useful
or believe to be beautiful."

17.text: These are words I live by for two reasons:

20.text: I love being surrounded by beauty,

22.text:
and my physical surroundings
directly affect my person.

26.text:
I can meditate and do yoga
till the cows come home,

28.text:
but if I'm surrounded by a mess
or just excess stuff in general,

32.text: I am unable to focus, to work or to relax.

37.text:
A serene space is a requirement
for my sanity's sake,

44.text:
Clear countertops,
an empty sink, clothes put away,

49.text: an empty desk to write on.

51.text:
That thought alone
both focuses and calms me,

54.text:
but the world I live in doesn't readily
meet my needs for simplicity.

58.text:
There are more products
available to us than ever before.

66.text:
but by the 1990s, 
there were 30,000 items.

71.text:
Let's take a look at a swanky
Fifth Avenue apartment in 1943.

79.text:
the negative space,
the simplicity of it all.

82.text: This is no longer the ideal,

85.text:
or, even if it is to some people,
it's nearly impossible to achieve.

89.text:
We, as a society, are accumulating
more than ever before,

93.text:
much of which can be
traced back 25 years ago,

96.text:
to when imports to America
increased exponentially,

99.text:
allowing huge amounts of cheap toys,
clothes, and electronics to come our way.

104.text: As a result of this accumulation,

107.text:
1 in 11 American households
spends over a thousand dollars a year

114.text:
One quarter of households
that have two car garages

118.text:
have so much stuff in there,
they can't park a car.

122.text:
And although US consumers
make up 3% of the world's children,

126.text: we buy 40% of the world's toys.

131.text:
So, while I find this New York apartment
to be the ideal for serenity,

136.text:
it wasn't necessarily
attractive to me always.

140.text:
I remember coveting
my collections as a little girl.

145.text:
There was the Berenstain Bear
book collection,

148.text:
the pencil collection
- I don't understand -

153.text:
the Teddy Bear collection,
and most importantly, my dolls.

156.text:
I wanted more of all of it.
I was a child of the 80s and 90s.

160.text:
More equaled better, which equaled
a happier, more fulfilling life, right?

165.text:
All I have to say is,
thank God for curiosity,

167.text:
because at 19, wanting to see the world,
I traveled abroad to India,

171.text: where I spent a good deal of time

172.text:
with a bunch of joyous children
that lived nearby me.

177.text:
but they had none of the collections
I had as a little girl.

180.text:
A broken bicycle tire 
could entertain them.

183.text:
And, when I say "entertain",
I'm talking unquenchable joy

187.text:
emanating from their beings
for hours at a time.

191.text:
What's more, my stuff
was limited on that semester.

194.text:
Due to weight restrictions
on Indian flights,

196.text:
I was only allotted 40 pounds 
in my backpack

199.text:
for the entire four months away,
and that doesn't add up too much.

202.text:
Yet, I felt unencumbered. 
Life got simpler.

207.text:
It was freeing, and my days became filled
with experiences, and not stuff.

213.text:
So, a seed was planted, but it wasn't
enough for me to change my habits.

220.text:
but I bought tons of trinkets
on that semester abroad.

225.text: Many were for friends and family,

230.text:
I shipped a huge box of tourist gear
back to my parent's house.

233.text:
But this was a unique circumstance, right?
Possessions equal memories, right?

239.text:
That box was proof
that my life had forever changed.

243.text:
It was proof that I was
an adventurer, a world traveler.

249.text:
How I came to believe otherwise
has been an eye-opening experience.

253.text:
I became a minimalist
when my passions and my goals

257.text: became more important than my possessions.

260.text:
Seven years ago, I started writing
in earnest. It took me by surprise.

264.text:
For the better part of my life,
I had dreamed about and pursued acting,

268.text: and here I was, rolling out of bed,

271.text:
planting myself at my desk,
beyond motivated, beyond fulfilled.

274.text: It was a passion I never knew I had.

277.text:
And I was willing to go
to any lengths to continue doing it

280.text: for as long as I was around.

283.text:
I was living in New York at the time,
sharing an apartment with two roommates,

287.text:
living paycheck to paycheck,
but I never felt lacking.

290.text:
After all, India had taught me
the value of the experience.

295.text:
But the more I wrote,
the more I needed space,

299.text: to daydream, to brainstorm, to create.

303.text:
So, here's the thing about necessity
being the mother of invention.

306.text:
My bedroom walls 
weren't going to magically expand.

309.text:
I had to create space
within the confines I was given,

312.text:
and it was a small bedroom,
packed with furniture, tons of books,

317.text:
and pages upon pages of files
from my graduate school years,

321.text:
proof that I had earned
my master's in Fine Arts.

327.text:
So, to create space, 
I started to declutter.

332.text:
I figured, "In this day an age,
when we store everything on our laptops,

337.text:
I scanned all my graduate school files,
and now that I had digital copies,

343.text:
and I even downsized my book collection,
which kind of felt sacrilegious,

348.text:
but, after doing so, I had
an empty shelf on my book case.

358.text:
So, I had decluttered to the essentials,
to what I knew to be useful,

364.text:
but I loved beauty, and I was in New York,
and style mattered to me,

368.text:
or, I should say, New York
cultivated my sense of style

371.text: because we would all agree, I had no idea

373.text:
how to put an outfit together
when I first arrived.

376.text:
So, once the city schooled me
in the fine art of dressing,

379.text:
the decluttering extended to my closet,
which was a good thing,

383.text:
because it was 
about the size of an iPhone.

386.text:
I got rid of anything that didn't 
make me feel like a million bucks.

390.text:
I was ruthless about it,
and the result was awesome.

392.text:
Gone were the days of hemming
and hawing in front of a mirror,

397.text:
When I did make purchases,
I found quality pieces that lasted,

402.text: paused to make sure I really loved them,

407.text:
I like to call this "the power of pause"
and "the art of conscious consumption".

413.text:
I used my teeny apartment,
my teeny bedroom,

416.text:
my teeny closet and my teeny budget
to develop these skills.

420.text: And I continue to use them today,

422.text:
even though my life couldn't look
more different if it tried.

428.text:
I moved in with a man

433.text:
and have moved

437.text: And big reveal: I'm about to have a baby.

444.text:
We might want to flag any doctors

While I moved to Indianapolis
with very few possessions,

453.text: I moved into his fully furnished house.

456.text:
And guess what the first thing

465.text:

So, when he put his foot down

I got to learn what his passions are,

491.text:
When we got married, we asked

498.text:
we welcomed the baby showers

502.text: I don't want minimalism to shackle me

505.text:
just like I don't want
to be shackled by stuff.

So, in this season of accumulation,
I have instituted the power of pause,

513.text:
and the art of conscious consumption
to design a baby registry,

I have called that list more
than you'd like to know

I will declutter what is
no longer necessary

Now I'm very aware that I could be
carrying a hoarder who -

"When the student is ready,
the teacher appears."

552.text:
So, while I look forward to discovering

558.text:
I also plan to use simple living

562.text:
When I teach my little girl

565.text:
it won't be just because

569.text:
It will also be 
because I want to teach her

571.text:
that she shares this world
with other people,

575.text:
and having a healthy respect

578.text:
is part and parcel to being

580.text: during our time here on Earth.

a place to return to,

And what if we chip away
all that is unnecessary,

616.text:
until we see what matters most,

622.text: What would that life be like?

625.text:
So, I just want to ask two things
of you before I wrap up.

629.text:
The first is I ask
that you go home tonight,

631.text:
and you find some quiet, serene space,

636.text:
and you imagine what your
masterpiece would look like,

639.text:
one that has nothing to do
with keeping up with the Joneses

644.text:
or how you think

654.text:
is that you wake up tomorrow,
and every tomorrow after that,
